segment.source: Auto-launching with AutoPlay
segment.target: Auto-launching with AutoPlay

segment.source: You can use AutoPlay to provide your app as an option when a user connects a device to their PC.
segment.target: You can use AutoPlay to provide your app as an option when a user connects a device to their PC.

segment.source: This includes non-volume devices such as a camera or media player, or volume devices such as a USB thumb drive, SD card, or DVD.
segment.target: This includes non-volume devices such as a camera or media player, or volume devices such as a USB thumb drive, SD card, or DVD.

segment.source: Auto-launching with AutoPlay
segment.target: Auto-launching with AutoPlay

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: You can use AutoPlay to provide your app as an option when a user connects a device to their PC.
segment.target: You can use AutoPlay to provide your app as an option when a user connects a device to their PC.

segment.source: This includes non-volume devices such as a camera or media player, or volume devices such as a USB thumb drive, SD card, or DVD.
segment.target: This includes non-volume devices such as a camera or media player, or volume devices such as a USB thumb drive, SD card, or DVD.

segment.source: You can also use AutoPlay to offer your app as an option when users share files between two PCs by using proximity (tapping).
segment.target: You can also use AutoPlay to offer your app as an option when users share files between two PCs by using proximity (tapping).

segment.source: Note If you are a device manufacturer and you want to associate your Windows Store device app as an AutoPlay handler for your device, you can identify that app in the device metadata.
segment.target: Note If you are a device manufacturer and you want to associate your Windows Store device app as an AutoPlay handler for your device, you can identify that app in the device metadata.

segment.source: For more info, see AutoPlay for Windows Store device apps.
segment.target: For more info, see AutoPlay for Windows Store device apps.

segment.source: Register for AutoPlay content
segment.target: Register for AutoPlay content

segment.source: You can register apps as options for AutoPlay content events.
segment.target: You can register apps as options for AutoPlay content events.

segment.source: AutoPlay content events are raised when a volume device such as a camera memory card, thumb drive, or DVD is inserted into the PC.
segment.target: AutoPlay content events are raised when a volume device such as a camera memory card, thumb drive, or DVD is inserted into the PC.

segment.source: Here we show how to identify your app as an AutoPlay option when a volume device from a camera is inserted.
segment.target: Here we show how to identify your app as an AutoPlay option when a volume device from a camera is inserted.

segment.source: In this tutorial, you created an app that displays image files or copies them to Pictures.
segment.target: In this tutorial, you created an app that displays image files or copies them to Pictures.

segment.source: You registered the app for the AutoPlay ShowPicturesOnArrival content event.
segment.target: You registered the app for the AutoPlay ShowPicturesOnArrival content event.

segment.source: AutoPlay also raises content events for content shared between PCs using proximity (tapping).
segment.target: AutoPlay also raises content events for content shared between PCs using proximity (tapping).

segment.source: You can use the steps and code in this section to handle files that are shared between PCs that use proximity.
segment.target: You can use the steps and code in this section to handle files that are shared between PCs that use proximity.

segment.source: The following table lists the AutoPlay content events that are available for sharing content by using proximity.
segment.target: The following table lists the AutoPlay content events that are available for sharing content by using proximity.

segment.source: Action
segment.target: Action

segment.source: AutoPlay content event
segment.target: AutoPlay content event

segment.source: Sharing music
segment.target: Sharing music

segment.source: PlayMusicFilesOnArrival
segment.target: PlayMusicFilesOnArrival

segment.source: Sharing videos
segment.target: Sharing videos

segment.source: PlayVideoFilesOnArrival
segment.target: PlayVideoFilesOnArrival

segment.source: When files are shared by using proximity, the Files property of the FileActivatedEventArgs object contains a reference to a root folder that contains all of the shared files.
segment.target: When files are shared by using proximity, the Files property of the FileActivatedEventArgs object contains a reference to a root folder that contains all of the shared files.

segment.source: Step 1: Create a new project and add AutoPlay declarations
segment.target: Step 1: Create a new project and add AutoPlay declarations

segment.source: Open Microsoft Visual Studio and select New Project from the File menu.
segment.target: Open Microsoft Visual Studio and select New Project from the File menu.

segment.source: In the Visual C# section, under Windows, select Blank App (Universal Windows).
segment.target: In the Visual C# section, under Windows, select Blank App (Universal Windows).

segment.source: Name the app AutoPlayDisplayOrCopyImages and click OK.
segment.target: Name the app AutoPlayDisplayOrCopyImages and click OK.

segment.source: Open the Package.appxmanifest file and select the Capabilities tab.
segment.target: Open the Package.appxmanifest file and select the Capabilities tab.

segment.source: Select the Removable Storage and Pictures Library capabilities.
segment.target: Select the Removable Storage and Pictures Library capabilities.

segment.source: This gives the app access to removable storage devices for camera memory, and access to local pictures.
segment.target: This gives the app access to removable storage devices for camera memory, and access to local pictures.

segment.source: In the manifest file, select the Declarations tab.
segment.target: In the manifest file, select the Declarations tab.

segment.source: In the Available Declarations drop-down list, select AutoPlay Content and click Add.
segment.target: In the Available Declarations drop-down list, select AutoPlay Content and click Add.

segment.source: Select the new AutoPlay Content item that was added to the Supported Declarations list.
segment.target: Select the new AutoPlay Content item that was added to the Supported Declarations list.

segment.source: An AutoPlay Content declaration identifies your app as an option when AutoPlay raises a content event.
segment.target: An AutoPlay Content declaration identifies your app as an option when AutoPlay raises a content event.

segment.source: The event is based on the content of a volume device such as a DVD or a thumb drive.
segment.target: The event is based on the content of a volume device such as a DVD or a thumb drive.

segment.source: AutoPlay examines the content of the volume device and determines which content event to raise.
segment.target: AutoPlay examines the content of the volume device and determines which content event to raise.

segment.source: If the root of the volume contains a DCIM, AVCHD, or PRIVATE\\ACHD folder, or if a user has enabled Choose what to do with each type of media in the AutoPlay Control Panel and pictures are found in the root of the volume, then AutoPlay raises the ShowPicturesOnArrival event.
segment.target: If the root of the volume contains a DCIM, AVCHD, or PRIVATE\\ACHD folder, or if a user has enabled Choose what to do with each type of media in the AutoPlay Control Panel and pictures are found in the root of the volume, then AutoPlay raises the ShowPicturesOnArrival event.

segment.source: In the Launch Actions section, enter the values from Table 1 below for the first launch action.
segment.target: In the Launch Actions section, enter the values from Table 1 below for the first launch action.

segment.source: In the Launch Actions section for the AutoPlay Content item, click Add New to add a second launch action.
segment.target: In the Launch Actions section for the AutoPlay Content item, click Add New to add a second launch action.

segment.source: Enter the values in Table 2 below for the second launch action.
segment.target: Enter the values in Table 2 below for the second launch action.

segment.source: In the Available Declarations drop-down list, select File Type Associations and click Add.
segment.target: In the Available Declarations drop-down list, select File Type Associations and click Add.

segment.source: In the Properties of the new File Type Associations declaration, set the Display Name field to AutoPlay Copy or Show Images and the Name field to image\_association1.
segment.target: In the Properties of the new File Type Associations declaration, set the Display Name field to AutoPlay Copy or Show Images and the Name field to image\_association1.

segment.source: In the Supported File Types section, click Add New.
segment.target: In the Supported File Types section, click Add New.

segment.source: Set the File Type field to .jpg.
segment.target: Set the File Type field to .jpg.

segment.source: In the Supported File Types section, set the File Type field of the new file association to .png.
segment.target: In the Supported File Types section, set the File Type field of the new file association to .png.

segment.source: For content events, AutoPlay filters out any file types that are not explicitly associated with your app.
segment.target: For content events, AutoPlay filters out any file types that are not explicitly associated with your app.

segment.source: Save and close the manifest file.
segment.target: Save and close the manifest file.

segment.source: Table 1
segment.target: Table 1

segment.source: Setting
segment.target: Setting

segment.source: Value
segment.target: Value

segment.source: Verb
segment.target: Verb

segment.source: show
segment.target: show

segment.source: Action Display Name
segment.target: Action Display Name

segment.source: Show Pictures
segment.target: Show Pictures

segment.source: Content Event
segment.target: Content Event

segment.source: ShowPicturesOnArrival
segment.target: ShowPicturesOnArrival

segment.source: The Action Display Name setting identifies the string that AutoPlay displays for your app.
segment.target: The Action Display Name setting identifies the string that AutoPlay displays for your app.

segment.source: The Verb setting identifies a value that is passed to your app for the selected option.
segment.target: The Verb setting identifies a value that is passed to your app for the selected option.

segment.source: You can specify multiple launch actions for an AutoPlay event and use the Verb setting to determine which option a user has selected for your app.
segment.target: You can specify multiple launch actions for an AutoPlay event and use the Verb setting to determine which option a user has selected for your app.

segment.source: You can tell which option the user selected by checking the verb property of the startup event arguments passed to your app.
segment.target: You can tell which option the user selected by checking the verb property of the startup event arguments passed to your app.

segment.source: You can use any value for the Verb setting except, open, which is reserved.
segment.target: You can use any value for the Verb setting except, open, which is reserved.

segment.source: Table 2
segment.target: Table 2

segment.source: Setting
segment.target: Setting

segment.source: Value
segment.target: Value

segment.source: Verb
segment.target: Verb

segment.source: copy
segment.target: copy

segment.source: Action Display Name
segment.target: Action Display Name

segment.source: Copy Pictures Into Library
segment.target: Copy Pictures Into Library

segment.source: Content Event
segment.target: Content Event

segment.source: ShowPicturesOnArrival
segment.target: ShowPicturesOnArrival

segment.target: Step 2: Add XAML UI

segment.source: Open the MainPage.xaml file and add the following XAML to the default Grid section.
segment.target: Open the MainPage.xaml file and add the following XAML to the default Grid section.

segment.target: Step 3: Add initialization code

segment.target: The code in this step checks the verb value in the Verb property, which is one of the startup arguments passed to the app during the OnFileActivated event.

segment.source: The code then calls a method related to the option that the user selected.
segment.target: The code then calls a method related to the option that the user selected.

segment.source: For the camera memory event, AutoPlay passes the root folder of the camera storage to the app.
segment.target: For the camera memory event, AutoPlay passes the root folder of the camera storage to the app.

segment.source: You can retrieve this folder from the first element of the Files property.
segment.target: You can retrieve this folder from the first element of the Files property.

segment.target: Open the App.xaml.cs file and add the following code to the App class.

segment.target: Note The and methods are added in the following steps.

segment.target: Step 4: Add code to display images

segment.source: In the MainPage.xaml.cs file add the following code to the MainPage class.
segment.target: In the MainPage.xaml.cs file add the following code to the MainPage class.

segment.target: Step 5: Add code to copy images

segment.target: In the MainPage.xaml.cs file add the following code to the MainPage class.

segment.source: Step 6: Build and run the app
segment.target: Step 6: Build and run the app

segment.source: Press F5 to build and deploy the app (in debug mode).
segment.target: Press F5 to build and deploy the app (in debug mode).

segment.source: To run your app, insert a camera memory card or another storage device from a camera into your PC.
segment.target: To run your app, insert a camera memory card or another storage device from a camera into your PC.

segment.source: Then, select one of the content event options that you specified in your package.appxmanifest file from the AutoPlay list of options.
segment.target: Then, select one of the content event options that you specified in your package.appxmanifest file from the AutoPlay list of options.

segment.source: This sample code only displays or copies pictures in the DCIM folder of a camera memory card.
segment.target: This sample code only displays or copies pictures in the DCIM folder of a camera memory card.

segment.source: If your camera memory card stores pictures in an AVCHD or PRIVATE\\ACHD folder, you will need to update the code accordingly.
segment.target: If your camera memory card stores pictures in an AVCHD or PRIVATE\\ACHD folder, you will need to update the code accordingly.

segment.source: Note If you don't have a camera memory card, you can use a flash drive if it has a folder named DCIM in the root and if the DCIM folder has a subfolder that contains images.
segment.target: Note If you don't have a camera memory card, you can use a flash drive if it has a folder named DCIM in the root and if the DCIM folder has a subfolder that contains images.

segment.source: Register for an AutoPlay device
segment.target: Register for an AutoPlay device

segment.source: You can register apps as options for AutoPlay device events.
segment.target: You can register apps as options for AutoPlay device events.

segment.source: AutoPlay device events are raised when a device is connected to a PC.
segment.target: AutoPlay device events are raised when a device is connected to a PC.

segment.source: Here we show how to identify your app as an AutoPlay option when a camera is connected to a PC.
segment.target: Here we show how to identify your app as an AutoPlay option when a camera is connected to a PC.

segment.source: The app registers as a handler for the WPD\\ImageSourceAutoPlay event.
segment.target: The app registers as a handler for the WPD\\ImageSourceAutoPlay event.

segment.source: This is a common event that the Windows Portable Device (WPD) system raises when cameras and other imaging devices notify it that they are an ImageSource using MTP.
segment.target: This is a common event that the Windows Portable Device (WPD) system raises when cameras and other imaging devices notify it that they are an ImageSource using MTP.

segment.source: For more info, see Windows Portable Devices.
segment.target: For more info, see Windows Portable Devices.

segment.source: Important The Windows.Devices.Portable.StorageDevice APIs are part of the desktop device family.
segment.target: Important The Windows.Devices.Portable.StorageDevice APIs are part of the desktop device family.

segment.source: Apps can use these APIs only on Windows 10 devices in the desktop device family, such as PCs.
segment.target: Apps can use these APIs only on Windows 10 devices in the desktop device family, such as PCs.

segment.source: Step 1: Create a new project and add AutoPlay declarations
segment.target: Step 1: Create a new project and add AutoPlay declarations

segment.source: Open Visual Studio and select New Project from the File menu.
segment.target: Open Visual Studio and select New Project from the File menu.

segment.source: In the Visual C# section, under Windows, select Blank App (Universal Windows).
segment.target: In the Visual C# section, under Windows, select Blank App (Universal Windows).

segment.source: Name the app AutoPlayDevice\_Camera and click OK.
segment.target: Name the app AutoPlayDevice\_Camera and click OK.

segment.source: Open the Package.appxmanifest file and select the Capabilities tab.
segment.target: Open the Package.appxmanifest file and select the Capabilities tab.

segment.source: Select the Removable Storage capability.
segment.target: Select the Removable Storage capability.

segment.source: This gives the app access to the data on the camera as a removable storage volume device.
segment.target: This gives the app access to the data on the camera as a removable storage volume device.

segment.source: In the manifest file, select the Declarations tab.
segment.target: In the manifest file, select the Declarations tab.

segment.source: In the Available Declarations drop-down list, select AutoPlay Device and click Add.
segment.target: In the Available Declarations drop-down list, select AutoPlay Device and click Add.

segment.source: Select the new AutoPlay Device item that was added to the Supported Declarations list.
segment.target: Select the new AutoPlay Device item that was added to the Supported Declarations list.

segment.source: An AutoPlay Device declaration identifies your app as an option when AutoPlay raises a device event for known events.
segment.target: An AutoPlay Device declaration identifies your app as an option when AutoPlay raises a device event for known events.

segment.source: In the Launch Actions section, enter the values in the table below for the first launch action.
segment.target: In the Launch Actions section, enter the values in the table below for the first launch action.

segment.source: In the Available Declarations drop-down list, select File Type Associations and click Add.
segment.target: In the Available Declarations drop-down list, select File Type Associations and click Add.

segment.source: In the Properties of the new File Type Associations declaration, set the Display Name field to Show Images from Camera and the Name field to camera\_association1.
segment.target: In the Properties of the new File Type Associations declaration, set the Display Name field to Show Images from Camera and the Name field to camera\_association1.

segment.source: In the Supported File Types section, click Add New (if needed).
segment.target: In the Supported File Types section, click Add New (if needed).

segment.source: Set the File Type field to .jpg.
segment.target: Set the File Type field to .jpg.

segment.source: In the Supported File Types section, click Add New again.
segment.target: In the Supported File Types section, click Add New again.

segment.source: Set the File Type field of the new file association to .png.
segment.target: Set the File Type field of the new file association to .png.

segment.source: For content events, AutoPlay filters out any file types that are not explicitly associated with your app.
segment.target: For content events, AutoPlay filters out any file types that are not explicitly associated with your app.

segment.source: Save and close the manifest file.
segment.target: Save and close the manifest file.

segment.target: Setting

segment.target: Value

segment.target: Verb

segment.target: show

segment.target: Action Display Name

segment.source: WPD\\ImageSource
segment.target: WPD\\ImageSource

segment.source: The Action Display Name setting identifies the string that AutoPlay displays for your app.
segment.target: The Action Display Name setting identifies the string that AutoPlay displays for your app.

segment.source: The Verb setting identifies a value that is passed to your app for the selected option.
segment.target: The Verb setting identifies a value that is passed to your app for the selected option.

segment.source: You can specify multiple launch actions for an AutoPlay event and use the Verb setting to determine which option a user has selected for your app.
segment.target: You can specify multiple launch actions for an AutoPlay event and use the Verb setting to determine which option a user has selected for your app.

segment.source: You can tell which option the user selected by checking the verb property of the startup event arguments passed to your app.
segment.target: You can tell which option the user selected by checking the verb property of the startup event arguments passed to your app.

segment.source: You can use any value for the Verb setting except, open, which is reserved.
segment.target: You can use any value for the Verb setting except, open, which is reserved.

segment.source: For an example of using multiple verbs in a single app, see Register for AutoPlay content.
segment.target: For an example of using multiple verbs in a single app, see Register for AutoPlay content.

segment.source: Step 2: Add assembly reference for the desktop extensions
segment.target: Step 2: Add assembly reference for the desktop extensions

segment.source: The APIs required to access storage on a Windows Portable Device, Windows.Devices.Portable.StorageDevice, are part of the desktop desktop device family.
segment.target: The APIs required to access storage on a Windows Portable Device, Windows.Devices.Portable.StorageDevice, are part of the desktop desktop device family.

segment.source: This means a special assembly is required to use the APIs and those calls will only work on a device in the desktop device family (such as a PC).
segment.target: This means a special assembly is required to use the APIs and those calls will only work on a device in the desktop device family (such as a PC).

segment.source: In Solution Explorer, right click on References and then Add Reference....
segment.target: In Solution Explorer, right click on References and then Add Reference....

segment.source: Expand Universal Windows and click Extensions.
segment.target: Expand Universal Windows and click Extensions.

segment.source: Then select Windows Desktop Extensions for the UWP and click OK.
segment.target: Then select Windows Desktop Extensions for the UWP and click OK.

segment.source: Step 3: Add XAML UI
segment.target: Step 3: Add XAML UI

segment.source: Open the MainPage.xaml file and add the following XAML to the default Grid section.
segment.target: Open the MainPage.xaml file and add the following XAML to the default Grid section.

segment.source: Step 4: Add activation code
segment.target: Step 4: Add activation code

segment.source: The code in this step references the camera as a StorageDevice by passing the device information Id of the camera to the FromId method.
segment.target: The code in this step references the camera as a StorageDevice by passing the device information Id of the camera to the FromId method.

segment.source: The device information Id of the camera is obtained by first casting the event arguments as DeviceActivatedEventArgs, and then getting the value from the DeviceInformationId property.
segment.target: The device information Id of the camera is obtained by first casting the event arguments as DeviceActivatedEventArgs, and then getting the value from the DeviceInformationId property.

segment.source: Open the App.xaml.cs file and add the following code to the App class.
segment.target: Open the App.xaml.cs file and add the following code to the App class.

segment.target: Note The method is added in the following step.

segment.source: Step 5: Add code to display device information
segment.target: Step 5: Add code to display device information

segment.source: You can obtain information about the camera from the properties of the StorageDevice class.
segment.target: You can obtain information about the camera from the properties of the StorageDevice class.

segment.source: The code in this step displays the device name and other info to the user when the app runs.
segment.target: The code in this step displays the device name and other info to the user when the app runs.

segment.source: The code then calls the GetImageList and GetThumbnail methods, which you will add in the next step, to display thumbnails of the images stored on the camera
segment.target: The code then calls the GetImageList and GetThumbnail methods, which you will add in the next step, to display thumbnails of the images stored on the camera

segment.source: In the MainPage.xaml.cs file, add the following code to the MainPage class.
segment.target: In the MainPage.xaml.cs file, add the following code to the MainPage class.

segment.source: Note The and methods are added in the following step.
segment.target: Note The and methods are added in the following step.

segment.source: Step 6: Add code to display images
segment.target: Step 6: Add code to display images

segment.source: The code in this step displays thumbnails of the images stored on the camera.
segment.target: The code in this step displays thumbnails of the images stored on the camera.

segment.source: The code makes asynchronous calls to the camera to get the thumbnail image.
segment.target: The code makes asynchronous calls to the camera to get the thumbnail image.

segment.source: However, the next asynchronous call doesn't occur until the previous asynchronous call completes.
segment.target: However, the next asynchronous call doesn't occur until the previous asynchronous call completes.

segment.source: This ensures that only one request is made to the camera at a time.
segment.target: This ensures that only one request is made to the camera at a time.

segment.target: In the MainPage.xaml.cs file, add the following code to the MainPage class.

segment.source: Step 7: Build and run the app
segment.target: Step 7: Build and run the app

segment.source: Press F5 to build and deploy the app (in debug mode).
segment.target: Press F5 to build and deploy the app (in debug mode).

segment.source: To run your app, connect a camera to your machine.
segment.target: To run your app, connect a camera to your machine.

segment.source: Then select the app from the AutoPlay list of options.
segment.target: Then select the app from the AutoPlay list of options.

segment.source: Note Not all cameras advertise for the WPD\\ImageSource AutoPlay device event.
segment.target: Note Not all cameras advertise for the WPD\\ImageSource AutoPlay device event.

segment.source: Configure removable storage
segment.target: Configure removable storage

segment.source: You can identify a volume device such as a memory card or thumb drive as an AutoPlay device when the volume device is connected to a PC.
segment.target: You can identify a volume device such as a memory card or thumb drive as an AutoPlay device when the volume device is connected to a PC.

segment.source: This is especially useful when you want to associate a specific app for AutoPlay to present to the user for your volume device.
segment.target: This is especially useful when you want to associate a specific app for AutoPlay to present to the user for your volume device.

segment.source: Here we show how to identify your volume device as an AutoPlay device.
segment.target: Here we show how to identify your volume device as an AutoPlay device.

segment.source: To identify your volume device as an AutoPlay device, add an autorun.inf file to the root drive of your device.
segment.target: To identify your volume device as an AutoPlay device, add an autorun.inf file to the root drive of your device.

segment.source: In the autorun.inf file, add a CustomEvent key to the AutoRun section.
segment.target: In the autorun.inf file, add a CustomEvent key to the AutoRun section.

segment.source: When your volume device connects to a PC, AutoPlay will find the autorun.inf file and treat your volume as a device.
segment.target: When your volume device connects to a PC, AutoPlay will find the autorun.inf file and treat your volume as a device.

segment.source: AutoPlay will create an AutoPlay event by using the name that you supplied for the CustomEvent key.
segment.target: AutoPlay will create an AutoPlay event by using the name that you supplied for the CustomEvent key.

segment.source: You can then create an app and register the app as a handler for that AutoPlay event.
segment.target: You can then create an app and register the app as a handler for that AutoPlay event.

segment.source: When the device is connected to the PC, AutoPlay will show your app as a handler for your volume device.
segment.target: When the device is connected to the PC, AutoPlay will show your app as a handler for your volume device.

segment.source: For more info on autorun.inf files, see autorun.inf entries.
segment.target: For more info on autorun.inf files, see autorun.inf entries.

segment.source: Step 1: Create an autorun.inf file
segment.target: Step 1: Create an autorun.inf file

segment.source: In the root drive of your volume device, add a file named autorun.inf.
segment.target: In the root drive of your volume device, add a file named autorun.inf.

segment.source: Open the autorun.inf file and add the following text.
segment.target: Open the autorun.inf file and add the following text.

segment.source: Step 2: Create a new project and add AutoPlay declarations
segment.target: Step 2: Create a new project and add AutoPlay declarations

segment.source: Open Visual Studio and select New Project from the File menu.
segment.target: Open Visual Studio and select New Project from the File menu.

segment.source: In the Visual C# section, under Windows, select Blank App (Universal Windows).
segment.target: In the Visual C# section, under Windows, select Blank App (Universal Windows).

segment.source: Name the application AutoPlayCustomEvent and click OK.
segment.target: Name the application AutoPlayCustomEvent and click OK.

segment.source: Open the Package.appxmanifest file and select the Capabilities tab.
segment.target: Open the Package.appxmanifest file and select the Capabilities tab.

segment.source: Select the Removable Storage capability.
segment.target: Select the Removable Storage capability.

segment.source: This gives the app access to the files and folders on removable storage devices.
segment.target: This gives the app access to the files and folders on removable storage devices.

segment.source: In the manifest file, select the Declarations tab.
segment.target: In the manifest file, select the Declarations tab.

segment.source: In the Available Declarations drop-down list, select AutoPlay Content and click Add.
segment.target: In the Available Declarations drop-down list, select AutoPlay Content and click Add.

segment.source: Select the new AutoPlay Content item that was added to the Supported Declarations list.
segment.target: Select the new AutoPlay Content item that was added to the Supported Declarations list.

segment.source: Note Alternatively, you can also choose to add an AutoPlay Device declaration for your custom AutoPlay event.
segment.target: Note Alternatively, you can also choose to add an AutoPlay Device declaration for your custom AutoPlay event.

segment.source: In the Launch Actions section for your AutoPlay Content event declaration, enter the values in the table below for the first launch action.
segment.target: In the Launch Actions section for your AutoPlay Content event declaration, enter the values in the table below for the first launch action.

segment.source: In the Available Declarations drop-down list, select File Type Associations and click Add.
segment.target: In the Available Declarations drop-down list, select File Type Associations and click Add.

segment.source: In the Properties of the new File Type Associations declaration, set the Display Name field to Show .ms Files and the Name field to ms\_association.
segment.target: In the Properties of the new File Type Associations declaration, set the Display Name field to Show .ms Files and the Name field to ms\_association.

segment.source: In the Supported File Types section, click Add New.
segment.target: In the Supported File Types section, click Add New.

segment.source: Set the File Type field to .ms.
segment.target: Set the File Type field to .ms.

segment.source: For content events, AutoPlay filters out any file types that aren't explicitly associated with your app.
segment.target: For content events, AutoPlay filters out any file types that aren't explicitly associated with your app.

segment.source: Save and close the manifest file.
segment.target: Save and close the manifest file.

segment.source: Setting
segment.target: Setting

segment.source: Value
segment.target: Value

segment.source: Verb
segment.target: Verb

segment.source: show
segment.target: show

segment.source: Action Display Name
segment.target: Action Display Name

segment.source: Show Files
segment.target: Show Files

segment.source: Content Event
segment.target: Content Event

segment.source: AutoPlayCustomEventQuickstart
segment.target: AutoPlayCustomEventQuickstart

segment.source: The Content Event value is the text that you supplied for the CustomEvent key in your autorun.inf file.
segment.target: The Content Event value is the text that you supplied for the CustomEvent key in your autorun.inf file.

segment.source: The Action Display Name setting identifies the string that AutoPlay displays for your app.
segment.target: The Action Display Name setting identifies the string that AutoPlay displays for your app.

segment.source: The Verb setting identifies a value that is passed to your app for the selected option.
segment.target: The Verb setting identifies a value that is passed to your app for the selected option.

segment.source: You can specify multiple launch actions for an AutoPlay event and use the Verb setting to determine which option a user has selected for your app.
segment.target: You can specify multiple launch actions for an AutoPlay event and use the Verb setting to determine which option a user has selected for your app.

segment.source: You can tell which option the user selected by checking the verb property of the startup event arguments passed to your app.
segment.target: You can tell which option the user selected by checking the verb property of the startup event arguments passed to your app.

segment.source: You can use any value for the Verb setting except, open, which is reserved.
segment.target: You can use any value for the Verb setting except, open, which is reserved.

segment.source: Step 3: Add XAML UI
segment.target: Step 3: Add XAML UI

segment.source: Open the MainPage.xaml file and add the following XAML to the default Grid section.
segment.target: Open the MainPage.xaml file and add the following XAML to the default Grid section.

segment.source: Step 4: Add activation code
segment.target: Step 4: Add activation code

segment.source: The code in this step calls a method to display the folders in the root drive of your volume device.
segment.target: The code in this step calls a method to display the folders in the root drive of your volume device.

segment.source: For the AutoPlay content events, AutoPlay passes the root folder of the storage device in the startup arguments passed to the application during the OnFileActivated event.
segment.target: For the AutoPlay content events, AutoPlay passes the root folder of the storage device in the startup arguments passed to the application during the OnFileActivated event.

segment.source: You can retrieve this folder from the first element of the Files property.
segment.target: You can retrieve this folder from the first element of the Files property.

segment.source: Open the App.xaml.cs file and add the following code to the App class.
segment.target: Open the App.xaml.cs file and add the following code to the App class.

segment.source: Note The method is added in the following step.
segment.target: Note The method is added in the following step.

segment.source: Step 5: Add code to display folders
segment.target: Step 5: Add code to display folders

segment.source: In the MainPage.xaml.cs file add the following code to the MainPage class.
segment.target: In the MainPage.xaml.cs file add the following code to the MainPage class.

segment.source: Step 6: Build and run the qpp
segment.target: Step 6: Build and run the qpp

segment.source: Press F5 to build and deploy the app (in debug mode).
segment.target: Press F5 to build and deploy the app (in debug mode).

segment.source: To run your app, insert a memory card or another storage device into your PC.
segment.target: To run your app, insert a memory card or another storage device into your PC.

segment.source: Then select your app from the list of AutoPlay handler options.
segment.target: Then select your app from the list of AutoPlay handler options.

segment.source: AutoPlay event reference
segment.target: AutoPlay event reference

segment.source: The AutoPlay system allows apps to register for a variety of device and volume (disk) arrival events.
segment.target: The AutoPlay system allows apps to register for a variety of device and volume (disk) arrival events.

segment.source: To register for AutoPlay content events, you must enable the Removable Storage capability in your package manifest.
segment.target: To register for AutoPlay content events, you must enable the Removable Storage capability in your package manifest.

segment.source: This table shows the events that you can register for and when they are raised.
segment.target: This table shows the events that you can register for and when they are raised.

segment.source: Scenario
segment.target: Scenario

segment.source: Event
segment.target: Event

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Using photos on a Camera
segment.target: Using photos on a Camera

segment.source: WPD\ImageSource
segment.target: WPD\ImageSource

segment.source: Raised for cameras that are identified as Windows Portable Devices and offer the ImageSource capability.
segment.target: Raised for cameras that are identified as Windows Portable Devices and offer the ImageSource capability.

segment.source: Using music on an audio player
segment.target: Using music on an audio player

segment.source: WPD\AudioSource
segment.target: WPD\AudioSource

segment.source: Raised for media players that are identified as Windows Portable Devices and offer the AudioSource capability.
segment.target: Raised for media players that are identified as Windows Portable Devices and offer the AudioSource capability.

segment.source: Using videos on a video camera
segment.target: Using videos on a video camera

segment.source: WPD\VideoSource
segment.target: WPD\VideoSource

segment.source: Raised for video cameras that are identified as Windows Portable Devices and offer the VideoSource capability.
segment.target: Raised for video cameras that are identified as Windows Portable Devices and offer the VideoSource capability.

segment.source: Access a connected flash drive or external hard drive
segment.target: Access a connected flash drive or external hard drive

segment.source: StorageOnArrival
segment.target: StorageOnArrival

segment.source: Raised when a drive or volume is connected to the PC.
segment.target: Raised when a drive or volume is connected to the PC.

segment.source: If the drive or volume contains a DCIM, AVCHD, or PRIVATE\ACHD folder in the root of the disk, the ShowPicturesOnArrival event is raised instead.
segment.target: If the drive or volume contains a DCIM, AVCHD, or PRIVATE\ACHD folder in the root of the disk, the ShowPicturesOnArrival event is raised instead.

segment.source: Using photos from mass storage (legacy)
segment.target: Using photos from mass storage (legacy)

segment.source: ShowPicturesOnArrival
segment.target: ShowPicturesOnArrival

segment.source: Raised when a drive or volume contains a DCIM, AVCHD, or PRIVATE\ACHD folder in the root of the disk.
segment.target: Raised when a drive or volume contains a DCIM, AVCHD, or PRIVATE\ACHD folder in the root of the disk.

segment.source: IIf a user has enabled Choose what to do with each type of media in the AutoPlay Control Panel, AutoPlay will examine a volume connected to the PC to determine the type of content on the disk.
segment.target: IIf a user has enabled Choose what to do with each type of media in the AutoPlay Control Panel, AutoPlay will examine a volume connected to the PC to determine the type of content on the disk.

segment.source: When pictures are found, ShowPicturesOnArrival is raised.
segment.target: When pictures are found, ShowPicturesOnArrival is raised.

segment.source: Receiving photos with Proximity Sharing (tap and send)
segment.target: Receiving photos with Proximity Sharing (tap and send)

segment.source: ShowPicturesOnArrival
segment.target: ShowPicturesOnArrival

segment.source: When users send content with using proximity (tap and send), AutoPlay will examine the shared files to determine the type of content.
segment.target: When users send content with using proximity (tap and send), AutoPlay will examine the shared files to determine the type of content.

segment.source: If pictures are found, ShowPicturesOnArrival is raised.
segment.target: If pictures are found, ShowPicturesOnArrival is raised.

segment.source: Using music from mass storage (legacy)
segment.target: Using music from mass storage (legacy)

segment.source: PlayMusicFilesOnArrival
segment.target: PlayMusicFilesOnArrival

segment.source: If a user has enabled Choose what to do with each type of media in the AutoPlay Control Panel, AutoPlay will examine a volume connected to the PC to determine the type of content on the disk.
segment.target: If a user has enabled Choose what to do with each type of media in the AutoPlay Control Panel, AutoPlay will examine a volume connected to the PC to determine the type of content on the disk.

segment.source: When music files are found, PlayMusicFilesOnArrival is raised.
segment.target: When music files are found, PlayMusicFilesOnArrival is raised.

segment.source: Receiving music with Proximity Sharing (tap and send)
segment.target: Receiving music with Proximity Sharing (tap and send)

segment.source: PlayMusicFilesOnArrival
segment.target: PlayMusicFilesOnArrival

segment.source: When users send content with using proximity (tap and send), AutoPlay will examine the shared files to determine the type of content.
segment.target: When users send content with using proximity (tap and send), AutoPlay will examine the shared files to determine the type of content.

segment.source: If music files are found, PlayMusicFilesOnArrival is raised.
segment.target: If music files are found, PlayMusicFilesOnArrival is raised.

segment.source: Using videos from mass storage (legacy)
segment.target: Using videos from mass storage (legacy)

segment.source: PlayVideoFilesOnArrival
segment.target: PlayVideoFilesOnArrival

segment.source: If a user has enabled Choose what to do with each type of media in the AutoPlay Control Panel,, AutoPlay will examine a volume connected to the PC to determine the type of content on the disk.
segment.target: If a user has enabled Choose what to do with each type of media in the AutoPlay Control Panel,, AutoPlay will examine a volume connected to the PC to determine the type of content on the disk.

segment.source: When video files are found, PlayVideoFilesOnArrival is raised.
segment.target: When video files are found, PlayVideoFilesOnArrival is raised.

segment.source: Receiving videos with Proximity Sharing (tap and send)
segment.target: Receiving videos with Proximity Sharing (tap and send)

segment.source: PlayVideoFilesOnArrival
segment.target: PlayVideoFilesOnArrival

segment.source: When users send content with using proximity (tap and send), AutoPlay will examine the shared files to determine the type of content.
segment.target: When users send content with using proximity (tap and send), AutoPlay will examine the shared files to determine the type of content.

segment.source: If video files are found, PlayVideoFilesOnArrival is raised.
segment.target: If video files are found, PlayVideoFilesOnArrival is raised.

segment.source: Handling mixed sets of files from a connected device
segment.target: Handling mixed sets of files from a connected device

segment.source: MixedContentOnArrival
segment.target: MixedContentOnArrival

segment.source: If a user has enabled Choose what to do with each type of media in the AutoPlay Control Panel, AutoPlay will examine a volume connected to the PC to determine the type of content on the disk.
segment.target: If a user has enabled Choose what to do with each type of media in the AutoPlay Control Panel, AutoPlay will examine a volume connected to the PC to determine the type of content on the disk.

segment.source: If no specific content type is found (for example, pictures), MixedContentOnArrival is raised.
segment.target: If no specific content type is found (for example, pictures), MixedContentOnArrival is raised.

segment.source: Handling mixed sets of files with Proximity Sharing (tap and send)
segment.target: Handling mixed sets of files with Proximity Sharing (tap and send)

segment.source: MixedContentOnArrival
segment.target: MixedContentOnArrival

segment.source: When users send content with using proximity (tap and send), AutoPlay will examine the shared files to determine the type of content.
segment.target: When users send content with using proximity (tap and send), AutoPlay will examine the shared files to determine the type of content.

segment.source: If no specific content type is found (for example, pictures), MixedContentOnArrival is raised.
segment.target: If no specific content type is found (for example, pictures), MixedContentOnArrival is raised.

segment.target: Handle video from optical media

segment.target: PlayDVDMovieOnArrival

segment.target: PlayBluRayOnArrival

segment.target: PlayDVDAudioOnArrival

segment.target: PlayEnhancedDVDOnArrival

segment.target: Handle writeable optical disks

segment.source: HandleCDBurningOnArrival
segment.target: HandleCDBurningOnArrival

segment.target: HandleDVDBurningOnArrival

segment.target: HandleBDBurningOnArrival

segment.source: Handle any other device or volume connection
segment.target: Handle any other device or volume connection

segment.source: UnknownContentOnArrival
segment.target: UnknownContentOnArrival

segment.source: Raised for all events in case content is found that does not match any of the AutoPlay content events.
segment.target: Raised for all events in case content is found that does not match any of the AutoPlay content events.

segment.source: Use of this event is not recommended.
segment.target: Use of this event is not recommended.

segment.source: You should only register your application for the specific AutoPlay events that it can handle.
segment.target: You should only register your application for the specific AutoPlay events that it can handle.

segment.source: You can specify that AutoPlay raise a custom AutoPlay Content event using the CustomEvent entry in the autorun.inf file for a volume.
segment.target: You can specify that AutoPlay raise a custom AutoPlay Content event using the CustomEvent entry in the autorun.inf file for a volume.

segment.source: For more info, see Autorun.inf entries.
segment.target: For more info, see Autorun.inf entries.

segment.source: You can register your app as an AutoPlay Content or AutoPlay Device event handler by adding an extension to the package.appxmanifest file for your app.
segment.target: You can register your app as an AutoPlay Content or AutoPlay Device event handler by adding an extension to the package.appxmanifest file for your app.

segment.source: If you are using Visual Studio, you can add an AutoPlay Content or AutoPlay Device declaration in the Declarations tab.
segment.target: If you are using Visual Studio, you can add an AutoPlay Content or AutoPlay Device declaration in the Declarations tab.

segment.source: If you are editing the package.appxmanifest file for your app directly, add an Extension element to your package manifest that specifies either windows.autoPlayContent or windows.autoPlayDevice as the Category.
segment.target: If you are editing the package.appxmanifest file for your app directly, add an Extension element to your package manifest that specifies either windows.autoPlayContent or windows.autoPlayDevice as the Category.

segment.source: For example, the following entry in the package manifest adds an AutoPlay Content extension to register the app as a handler for the ShowPicturesOnArrival event.
segment.target: For example, the following entry in the package manifest adds an AutoPlay Content extension to register the app as a handler for the ShowPicturesOnArrival event.
